subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to get test's name in JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Hello David, Gabriel, Thanks for your support, i could find any other simple way. I had to implement a custom runner....This was the only way out... As Gabriel
messageBody:
Hello David, Gabriel,

Thanks for your support, i could find any other simple way. I had to implement a custom runner....This was the only way out...

As Gabriel rightly pointed out, this is by design and one has to override testStarted and testFinished methods....

thanks again for your help
regards
Vasudevan


----- Original Message ----
From: David Saff <saff@...>
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 11, 2007 9:04:41 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to get test's name in JUnit 4

On 1/9/07, gabrielcooper <gabriel.cooper@ jtv.com> wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups. com, "Mike Bria" <bria526xp@. ..> wrote:
> >
> > Gabriel --
> >
> > I can't figure out how to get the test name, short of invoking the
> > test yourself (via the "main" or something similar). Sorry.
> >
> > That said, I'm very curious why you would want to use the test name,
> > particularly in the manner indicated by your example below. Could you
> > expand?
>
> Well, it turns out they don't use it in the actual test case, but in
> the setUp/tearDown instead. Specifically to insert into/delete from a
> database with test-specific data, or in another case, to load only a
> subset of the spring wiring based on the name to improve on testing
> loadtimes.
>
> Anyway...
>
> It seems like the RunListeneer would have a reference to the currently
> running test, simply because of its "testStarted" and "testFinished"
> functions:
>
> /**
> * Called when an atomic test is about to be started.
> * @param description the description of the test that is about to be run
> * (generally a class and method name)
> */
> public void testStarted( Description description) throws Exception {
> }
>
> Is it possible to get access to this from within the test class
> itself?

No, by design. Sorry about that.

> If not, it seems like I'd have to write a custom Runner, but
> I'm having trouble finding information on creating Runners. Are there
> any known resources for JUnit 4?

Information on custom runners is currently somewhat lacking. It
appears from your later message that you've somewhat successfully
navigating the waters. Any interest in writing up a short blog entry
or article on your experiences? Thanks,

David Saff
